text: I really believe that it's never a bad thing, it's always a better thing to have more feedback. And so, often, I think you don't necessarily want to be like, 'Oh, we have the one review meeting and that's the one in which we get everyone's opinions out and we make all these decisions, and then we're done.' I think about product and feedback as just the more, the better.
speaker: Julie Zhuo
context: Lenny asks Julie about how companies should structure product review meetings and design critiques. Julie explains her philosophy on gathering feedback during product development. She emphasizes that feedback collection should be an ongoing process rather than a single decisive meeting, and that getting diverse perspectives from different groups (designers, team members, external users, target customers) will all provide valuable but potentially contradictory insights.
text_ko: 저는 피드백은 많을수록 결코 나쁜 게 아니라 항상 더 좋은 거라고 정말 믿어요. 그래서 종종 '한 번의 리뷰 미팅(review meeting)에서만 다들 의견을 모아서 모든 결정을 내리고 끝내자'라고 할 필요는 없다고 생각해요. 저는 프로덕트(product)와 관련해서도 피드백은 그냥 많을수록 좋다고 봐요.
text_zh: 我觉得反馈这个事情，永远不嫌多，越多越好。所以我经常想，你不能说"哦，我们就开这一次评审会，大家把意见都说完，决策都做完，然后就结束了。"我对产品和反馈的看法就是，多多益善。
text_es: Yo creo firmemente que nunca está de más tener más retroalimentación (feedback), siempre es mejor. Y por eso, muchas veces pienso que no necesariamente querés decir 'Bueno, tenemos esa única reunión de revisión donde sacamos todas las opiniones, tomamos todas las decisiones, y ya está.' Yo veo el producto y la retroalimentación (feedback) como que mientras más, mejor.
key_sentence: More feedback is always better for product development.

text: The number one advice that I always have for people when talking about product sensor or product thinking is it's just really about observation and it's about curiosity and can start by first observing yourself. Every time you're going to go and use something, every time you're going to have a new experience, you download an app, you try something new, it's take the moment to reflect on your emotion or your assumption at every step.
speaker: Julie Zhuo
context: Lenny asks Julie for advice on how people can develop better product sense and product thinking skills. Julie explains that developing product intuition starts with careful self-observation - paying attention to your own user experience when trying new products or services. This involves reflecting on emotions, assumptions, and behaviors at each step of the user journey, from what motivated you to try something to where you got confused or excited during the experience.
text_ko: 제가 제품 센서(product sensor)나 제품 사고(product thinking)에 대해 얘기할 때 항상 제일 먼저 드리는 조언은, 사실 그냥 관찰하고 호기심을 가지라는 거예요. 그건 먼저 자기 자신을 관찰하는 것부터 시작할 수 있어요. 뭔가를 쓰거나 새로운 경험을 할 때—앱을 다운받거나 새로운 걸 시도할 때마다—매 단계에서 느끼는 감정이나 가지고 있는 가정을 잠깐씩 되돌아보세요.
text_zh: 我给大家谈产品感觉或者产品思维时，最重要的一个建议就是，其实就是要多观察，要有好奇心，而且可以先从观察自己开始。每次你要去用什么东西，每次你要体验新的东西，下载个app，尝试新玩意儿的时候，都花点时间想想你在每个步骤中的感受和想法是什么。
text_es: El consejo más importante que siempre doy cuando hablamos de intuición de producto o pensamiento de producto es que realmente se trata de observación y curiosidad, y puedes empezar observándote a ti mismo. Cada vez que vayas a usar algo, cada vez que tengas una experiencia nueva, te descargues una app o pruebes algo diferente, tómate un momento para reflexionar sobre tu emoción o lo que asumes en cada paso.
key_sentence: Product thinking starts with observation and reflecting on your emotions.

text: Being in an uncomfortable situation, being in a position where you feel like, Hey, do I really know how to do this? I've not prepared for it is kind of coin sides with the fastest and most intense periods of growth in one's career. And I started to realize, well, maybe it's not so much of a bad thing.
speaker: Julie Zhuo
context: Lenny asks Julie about her rapid career progression from designer to VP of Design at Facebook, and how others can achieve similar success. Julie explains that she experienced imposter syndrome for 7-8 years, constantly feeling unprepared for her roles. However, she came to realize that feeling uncomfortable and unprepared is actually the flip side of experiencing rapid professional growth - when you're constantly challenged by new situations, you're forced to learn and develop quickly.
vocabulary_highlights: not so much of a bad thing
text_ko: 불편한 상황에 놓여서 ‘이걸 정말 할 줄 아는 걸까? 준비가 안 됐는데…’라고 느낄 때가 경력에서 가장 빠르고 강렬하게 성장하는 시기와 종종 동전의 양면이에요. 그래서 이게 꼭 나쁜 것만은 아닐지도 모르겠다고 생각하기 시작했어요.
text_zh: 处在一个让你不舒服的环境里，感觉"哎呀，我真的会做这个吗？我根本没准备好啊"——其实这种状态往往和职场上最快速、最强烈的成长期是一体两面的。后来我慢慢意识到，这可能也不是什么坏事。
text_es: Estar en una situación incómoda, estar en una posición donde sientes como que "¿de verdad sé hacer esto? No me he preparado para esto" va de la mano con los períodos de crecimiento más rápidos e intensos en tu carrera. Y empecé a darme cuenta de que, bueno, tal vez no es algo tan malo después de todo.
key_sentence: Uncomfortable situations coin sides with intense growth periods.

text: The most important feedback I would say is focus on identifying the problem and making it really clear for the other person, the person you're giving feedback to, what is the problem. There's a lot of assumptions that are already in place. You are giving that because you assume the current thing is insufficient in some way, and it's maybe not ideal at being clear, or it is forgetting to bring some important value prop, or maybe yellow just makes this whole thing look pukey or whatever it is.
speaker: Julie Zhuo
context: Lenny asks Julie for advice on how colleagues (PMs, engineers, data scientists) should give feedback to designers during critiques. Julie emphasizes that people should focus on clearly articulating the underlying problem rather than jumping straight to solutions. She explains that when people say things like 'make the logo purple' or 'add this feature,' they're making assumptions about solutions without first establishing what specific problem needs to be solved.
text_ko: 제가 생각하는 가장 중요한 피드백은 문제를 찾아내는 데 집중하고, 그 문제가 피드백을 받는 사람에게 뭔지 정말 분명하게 알려줘야 한다는 거예요. 이미 많은 가정(assumptions)이 깔려 있는 경우가 많고요. 보통은 지금 상태가 뭔가 부족하다고 가정해서 피드백을 주는 건데, 설명이 애매하다든가 중요한 가치 제안(value prop)을 빠뜨리고 있다든가, 아니면 단순히 노란색 때문에 전체적으로 보기 안 좋게 보일 수도 있고, 뭐 그런 식이에요.
text_zh: 我觉得最重要的反馈就是要把问题说清楚，让对方真正明白问题出在哪儿。其实很多时候我们心里已经有各种假设了，你之所以要给反馈，肯定是觉得现在这个东西有什么地方不够好，可能是表达不够清晰，或者忘了突出一些重要的卖点(value prop)，再或者就是黄色让整个东西看起来很恶心，反正就是各种问题。
text_es: Lo más importante al dar feedback, yo diría que es enfocarte en identificar bien el problema y dejárselo súper claro a la otra persona, a quien le estás dando el feedback, cuál es exactamente el problema. Hay un montón de suposiciones que ya están ahí desde el principio. Tú estás dando ese feedback porque asumes que lo que hay ahora no está funcionando del todo bien, y tal vez no está siendo lo suficientemente claro, o se está olvidando de resaltar alguna propuesta de valor (value prop) importante, o a lo mejor ese color amarillo hace que todo se vea horrible, o lo que sea.
key_sentence: Focus on identifying the problem and making it clear.

text: What actually started me on this writing journey was a piece of feedback I got during a performance review cycle, and I remember I was talking to my manager and he shared that, 'Hey, one of the pieces of something you should work on, an area of growth is that you have a lot of really great ideas, and you're always really engaged whenever discussions happen in a small forum, one on one, or there's like two or three people in the room, but whenever there's a large room, we're talking about seven people, 10 people, 15 people, you're just sort of quiet and you're not really telling your perspective.'
speaker: Julie Zhuo
context: Lenny asks Julie about what got her started with writing and what impact it has had on her career. Julie explains that her writing journey began as a response to performance feedback about her reluctance to speak up in large meetings. Her manager pointed out that while she was engaged in small group discussions, she became quiet in larger forums with 7-15 people, and suggested she work on contributing her perspective in those settings.
text_ko: 사실 제가 이 글쓰기 여정을 시작하게 된 계기는 성과 리뷰에서 받은 피드백이었어요. 그때 매니저와 이야기하면서 그가 이렇게 말했어요. "너는 정말 좋은 아이디어가 많고, 소규모 포럼이나 일대일 대화에서는 항상 적극적으로 참여하는데, 큰 방에서는, 예를 들어 7명, 10명, 15명 정도가 모이면 좀 조용해지고 네 의견을 잘 이야기하지 않는 것 같아."
text_zh: 其实我开始写作这条路，完全是因为一次绩效评估(performance review)时收到的反馈。我记得当时跟我老板聊天，他跟我说："嘿，有个地方你需要提升一下，就是你其实想法挺多的，也很不错，平时小范围讨论的时候，比如一对一聊天，或者就两三个人在场的时候，你总是很积极参与，但是一到人多的场合，七八个人、十来个人、十五个人这种大会议，你就不怎么说话了，也不太表达自己的观点。"
text_es: Lo que realmente me llevó a empezar este camino de escribir fue un comentario que me dieron en una evaluación de desempeño. Me acuerdo que estaba hablando con mi jefe y me dijo: "Oye, algo en lo que deberías trabajar, un área de mejora, es que tienes ideas muy buenas y siempre participas mucho cuando hay conversaciones en grupos pequeños, cuando estamos uno a uno o cuando somos dos o tres personas, pero cuando hay mucha gente en la sala, digamos siete, diez, quince personas, como que te quedas callado y no compartes realmente tu punto de vista."
key_sentence: You're not telling your perspective in larger forums.

text: My number one advice is try to find an angle that's going to work for you because if you find yourself writing for your audience, if you find yourself writing because you want likes or you want a certain number of views, that actually is a really hard barrier to overcome because you don't have control over all of that. But if you write because you're trying to work on a particular key skill, whether it is clarity of thinking, whether it's helping you work through some stuff that's complicated in your mind, whether it's just, again, working on being more comfortable, putting your voice out there, then make it a goal, but make it a action goal.
speaker: Julie Zhuo
context: Lenny asks Julie if she would recommend writing as a tool for others who want to work on specific skills like clarity of communication. Julie responds with advice for people who want to start writing but find it difficult. She emphasizes that writing should be driven by personal development goals rather than external validation like likes or views, since you can't control audience response but you can control your own actions and skill development.
text_ko: 제일 먼저 드리고 싶은 조언은 본인에게 통할 만한 각도(approach)를 찾아보라는 거예요. 청중(audience)을 위해 쓰거나 좋아요나 특정 조회수 때문에 쓰게 되면 그런 건 통제가 잘 안 돼서 넘기기 정말 힘든 장벽이 되거든요. 대신 특정 핵심 역량(key skill)을 키우기 위해, 사고의 명확성(clarity of thinking)을 다듬기 위해, 머릿속 복잡한 걸 정리하기 위해, 혹은 그냥 목소리를 내는 데 더 익숙해지기 위해 쓴다면 목표를 세우되 그냥 목표가 아니라 실행 목표(action goal)로 세우세요.
text_zh: 我的头号建议就是，你得找到一个适合自己的切入点。因为如果你老想着为观众写，或者就想着要多少赞、多少浏览量，这其实特别难突破，因为这些东西你根本控制不了。但是如果你写作是为了锻炼某个核心技能，比如让思路更清晰，或者帮你理清一些复杂的想法，再或者就是让自己更敢于表达观点，那就把这个当目标，但一定要是个行动目标。
text_es: Mi consejo número uno es que encuentres un enfoque que te funcione, porque si te pones a escribir para tu audiencia, si escribes porque quieres likes o un cierto número de visualizaciones, eso en realidad es una barrera súper difícil de superar porque no tienes control sobre todo eso. Pero si escribes porque estás tratando de trabajar en una habilidad clave específica, ya sea para tener más claridad mental, ya sea para ayudarte a procesar cosas que están complicadas en tu cabeza, o simplemente para sentirte más cómodo poniendo tu voz ahí afuera, entonces hazlo tu meta, pero que sea una meta de acción.
key_sentence: Find an angle that works for you and set an action goal.
